gr.forth.ics.swkm.model2
Interface Model

All Known Implementing Classes:
ModelImpl
public interface Model

An RDF model. A model consists of a set of triples, which in turn contain three RdfNode RDF nodes (a subject, a predicate, and an object). Also, triples are grouped into named graphs. A named graph contains a set of triples, and a single triple can be contained in multiple named graphs.

Three kinds of RDF nodes are supported:

  • Resources, which are nodes identified by a URI
  • Literals, which have a simple literal value
  • Blank nodes, which have a locally (per RDF document) scoped identifier (which is not universally unique, contrary to a resource.

Distinction between values and nodes

It is important to understand the distinction between values (URIs, literals, blank node identifiers) and the nodes of a model that correspond to them. Multiple value objects can be created with the same value, but in a model only a single node can ever be created with the same value. This implies a mapping between values and nodes, i.e. all equal values map to the same node. The model manages this mapping. To obtain a node for a value, the various mapping methods should be used (see map(String), mapResource(Uri), mapResource(String), mapLiteral(Literal), mapBlankNode(String), mapObjectNode(String)). The mapping methods return nodes that can be used to create triples.

Triples are formed with nodes. Triples can be added through add(Resource, ObjectNode, Resource, RdfNode) or add(). The first takes all the required nodes directly, while the second offer a more convenient way to add triples without caring so much about explicit mappings. It is illegal to try to add a triple using nodes of another model. The foreign nodes must be mapped to this model instead, simply using RdfNode.mappedTo(Model).

Nodes have an associated type, see for details the Node typing section in RdfNode.

The model offers ways to find the nodes of a type, see findNodes(RdfType, RdfType[]) and namedGraphs().

Triples must be contained at least in one named graph. If a triple is removed from the last graph that contained it, it is removed from the model as well. For convenience, when adding a triple, null may be specified as the named graph of the triple, which is equivalent to the default named graph.

A model can answer simple triple queries, of the form (?namedGraph, ?subject, ?predicate, ?object), where any part can be fixed or can be left as a "wildcard" (i.e. to match anything). See triples() for details.

Apart from the triple-based access, a more object oriented access is offered. See RdfNode and particularly the asXXX methods.

Deleting triples

Triples may be deleted by several ways. See delete(Triple), delete(Iterable), and also Triple.delete(). Deleting multiple triples in a single call can be faster that deleting triples one by one, but it is not guarranteed. Another way to delete triples is through triples(), which is also used to answer triple queries. When the triple query is specified, if, instead of Model.QueryBuilder.fetch(), Model.QueryBuilder.delete() is called, all the triples that would normally be returned with the specified query are deleted. See triples() for usage examples.

Redundant triples can be deleted from a model with the Inference.reduce(Model) method; see its specification for details on what consistutes a redundant triple.

All methods that take instances of RdfNode may throw ClassCastException when the RdfNode instances are created using a different Model implementation.

All methods of this type throw NullPointerException for null arguments, unless otherwise specified.

Author:
Andreou Dimitris, email: jim.andreou (at) gmail (dot) com
See Also:
"Discussion on the semantics of rdfs:Resource, rdfs:Class, rdf:Property" for a reference of supported RDF typing rules., Node typing section in RdfNode, RdfNode

Method Detail

add

Triple add(Resource namedGraph,
           ObjectNode subject,
           Resource predicate,
           RdfNode object)
Adds a triple with the specified named graph, subject, predicate and object into this model, if not already there.

A distinct Triple instance is created per different combination of subject-predicate-object added in this model, not per different named graph. For example, calling this method with arguments:

  • <G1, S, P, O>, and
  • <G2, S, P, O>,
A single triple (S, P, O) instance would be created, that would be contained in both graphs G1 and G2.

Parameters:
namedGraph - the named graph that the added triple belongs. If null, defaultNamedGraph() is assumed
subject - the subject of the triple
predicate - the predicate of the triple
object - the object of the triple
Returns:
the added Triple, which will have the same subject, predicate and object as the parameters of this invocation, and will be also contained in the specified named graph
Throws:
IllegalArgumentException - if any node is given that is not owned by this model (i.e. it is a node of another model).
ValidationException - if the added triple creates a node typing error
See Also:
add()

add

Model.AddContext add()
Adds a triple in a step-by-step fashion. The procedure of adding a triple is:
  • (optionally) define a named graph for the triple
  • define the subject
  • define the predicate
  • define the object
When the workflow is completed, the designated triple is added. This way of adding a triple is in some cases more convenient than add(Resource, ObjectNode, Resource, RdfNode), because instead of needing, for each argument, to have the respective RdfNode (which for example may be obtained by mapping a Uri to a Resource), convenient overloadings are offered, which accept simple values (and automatically map them to nodes).

Example of adding a triple in the default graph: 

Model model = ...;
String subjectURI = ...;
String predicateURI =...;
Literal literal = ...;
Triple triple = model.add().s(subjectURI).p(predicateURI).o(literal);

Another example of adding a triple in the default graph: 

Model model = ...;
String graphURI = ...;
BlankNode subject = ...;
Uri predicateURI =...;
String literal = ...;
Triple triple = model.add().g(graphURI).s(subject).p(predicateURI).o(literal);

Returns:
an object to be used to add a triple in a step-by-step fashion

delete

boolean delete(Triple triple)
Deletes a single triple from this model.

Note: It should be more efficient to delete a bunch of triples at once with delete(Iterable) rather than one by one with this method.

Important: After triple deletions, the typing of the nodes is guarranteed to remain valid and consistent, but it is no longer guarranteed to be minimal. Strongly consider invoking retypeNodes() after triple deletions (see the method specification for further details).

Parameters:
triple - the triple to delete (must be non-null)
Returns:
whether the triple was actually deleted. If the triple did not exist in this model false is returned

delete

boolean delete(Iterable<Triple> triples)
Deletes triples from this model.

Important: After triple deletions, the typing of the nodes is guarranteed to remain valid and consistent, but it is no longer guarranteed to be minimal. Strongly consider invoking retypeNodes() after triple deletions (see the method specification for further details).

Parameters:
triples - the triples to delete (both the Iterable and the triples themselves must be non-null)
Returns:
whether any triple was actually deleted

retypeNodes

void retypeNodes()
Recalculates the types of every RdfNode, by reconsidering all triples of this model.

This may only be useful after triple deletions. After triple deletions, the typing of the nodes is guarranteed to remain valid and consistent, but it is no longer guarranteed to be minimal. For example if, after some deletions, this triple remains in the model: <A rdfs:subClassOf B>, with no other triples containing A or B, they might have the type of RdfType.METACLASS, which is an acceptable interpretation, though if the triple was to be added for the first time, the types of A, B would be RdfType.CLASS (a type that allows further transition to METACLASS in some cases, while the opposite is not true).

Note that having a non-minimal typing may cause erroneous validation errors, if more triples are added to the model. Continuing the above example, the triple <A rdfs:subClassOf rdfs:Resource> would cause an error if A was left as a METACLASS (which will be the case, if A was indeed a METACLASS, and merely some triples that inferred this type were deleted), since this would only be allowed if A was interpreted as a CLASS.

In summary, after triple deletions, if the minimal typing is required (which is what is produced when triples are only added to a model), invoke this method. If more triples are going to be added, consider whether they might cause erroneous typing errors, or take the safe route and invoke this method.

mapObjectNode

ObjectNode mapObjectNode(String uriOrId)
                         throws Uri.UriFormatException
Maps a URI or blank node identifier to a unique node of this model, creating such a node if necessary.

To determine whether a Uri or a BlankNode will be returned, the following steps will take place:

  • If uriOrId cannot be parsed to a Uri (with Uri.tryParse(String), then the only option is to treat it as a blank node identifier.
  • If there is already a Resource in this model with the same URI, then it is returned.
  • If there is already a BlankNode in this model with the same blank node identifier, then it is returned.
  • If still nothing has been returned, delegate to mapResource(String).

Parameters:
uriOrId - the URI or the blank node identifier to uniquely map to a node
Returns:
the node that the specified URI or blank node identifier (according to the above rules) uniquely (in this model) maps to
Throws:
Uri.UriFormatException - if no existing Resource or BlankNode was found with the same URI or blank node identifier, respectively, and uriOrId cannot be parsed to a Uri (via Uri.parse(String)
See Also:
Distinction between values and nodes

map

RdfNode map(String uriOrIdOrLiteral)
            throws Uri.UriFormatException
Maps a URI or blank node identifier or a literal to a unique node of this model, creating such a node if necessary.

To determine whether a Uri or a BlankNode will be returned, the following steps will take place:

  • If uriOrIdOrLiteral can be parsed to a Literal (via Literal.tryParse(String)), delegate to mapLiteral(String).
  • Otherwise, delegate to mapObjectNode(String)

Parameters:
uriOrIdOrLiteral - the URI or the blank node identifier or literal to uniquely map to a node
Returns:
the node that the specified argument (according to the above rules) uniquely (in this model) maps to
Throws:
Uri.UriFormatException - if uriOrIdOrLiteral cannot be parsed to a Literal (via Literal.tryParse(String)) and mapObjectNode(String) throws this exception
See Also:
Distinction between values and nodes

triples

Model.QueryBuilder triples()
Builds a triple query in a step-by-step fashion. The procedure of adding a triple is:
  • (Optionally) Define a specific named graph.
  • (Optionally) Define a specific subject.
  • (Optionally) Define a specific predicate.
  • (Optionally) Define a specific object.
Each parameter specification allows only triples with the same value at that position. For example, creating a query with subject "A", only selects triples that do have a subject "A". If multiple options are specified, only triples matching all options are selected. For example, creating a query with subject "A" and object "B" will select triples like <A p1 B>, <A p2 B> but will not select triples like <A p B1>, <A1 p B> etc.

Specifying no option at all designates the query that selects all existing triples.

A triple is allowed to be reported more than once in the query results, if it belongs to more than one named graph, and the query does not request a specific named graph.

Example of selecting all rdfs:subClassOf triples: 

Model model = ...;
Triples triples = model.triples()
      .p(RdfSchema.SUBCLASSOF)
      .fetch();

Example of selecting all triples with a specific subject, belonging to a specific graph: 

Model model = ...;
String graph = ...; //could be a Uri or a Resource too
String subject = ...; //could be a Uri or a Resource or a BlankNode too
Triples triples = model.triples()
      .g(graph)
      .s(subject)
      .fetch();

Returned Triples can be iterated simply: 

for (Triple triple : triples) {
   //...
}

The returned Triples object can also be used to subselect just a specific component of the triples, for example it is easy to select just the subject nodes, like this: 

for (ObjectNode subject : triples.subjects()) {
   //...
}
See Triples for more details.

A triple query, apart from reporting triples, can also be used to delete selected triples. Just substitute the final fetch() call with a delete() call. For example, this deletes all the triples of a specific named graph: 

Model model = ...;
Resource graph = ...;
Triples triples = model.triples()
      .g(graph)
      .delete();

Returns:
an object to be used to create a triple query in a step-by-step fashion, in order to select and report or delete triples

findNodes

Iterable<RdfNode> findNodes(RdfType firstType,
                            RdfType... restTypes)
Returns all nodes of this model that their type is equal to one of the specified types.

Parameters:
firstType - one of the types of the returned nodes
restTypes - the rest of the types of the returned nodes
Returns:
all nodes of this model with type included in the specified types

findSchemaNodes

Iterable<Resource> findSchemaNodes(Uri namespace,
                                   RdfType firstType,
                                   RdfType... restTypes)
Returns all resources of this model that their type is equal to one of the specified types and the namespace part of their URI matches the specified namespace.

Parameters:
namespace - the namespace part of the URI of the returned resources
firstType - one of the types of the returned nodes. They must be schema, i.e. one of the following: [CLASS, PROPERTY, METACLASS, METAPROPERTY]
restTypes - the rest of the types of the returned nodes, which should also be schema.
Returns:
all resources of this model with type included in the specified types and have the specified namespace part
Throws:
IllegalArgumentException - if the specified namespace Uri has a non-empty local part

namedGraphs

Iterable<Resource> namedGraphs()
Returns the named graphs of this model.

Equivalent to calling nodesOfType(RdfType.NAMED_GRAPH)

Returns:
the named graphs of this model

namespaces

Set<Uri> namespaces()
Returns all namespaces of this model. A namespace is defined if there exists a schema resource in a triple of this model, whereas its namespace part is the namespace. In other words, if there is schema resource res, then res.getUri().getNamespaceUri() will be returned from this method.

Returns:
all namespaces of this model

defaultNamedGraph

Resource defaultNamedGraph()
Returns the default named graph of this model. Triples that are added to a null named graph (i.e. using null as a named graph in add(Resource, ObjectNode, Resource, RdfNode) method) are added to this named graph.

Returns:
the default named graph of this model

isInferable

boolean isInferable(ObjectNode subject,
                    Resource predicate,
                    RdfNode object)
Returns whether the specified triple can be inferred by the present model. To invoke this operation, subject, predicate and object must have been specified, but no graph component.

A triple <S P O> is considered inferable if any of the following conditions hold:

  • The triple <S P O> exists verbatim in the model
  • If P is rdfs:subClassOf or rdfs:subPropertyOf, and S is a (direct or indirect) descendant of O
  • If P is rdf:type and there is a triple <S rdf:type X> where X is a (direct or indirect) descendant of O
  • If there is a triple <S P2 O> where P2 is a subproperty of P

Parameters:
subject - the subject of the triple
predicate - the predicate of the triple
object - the object of the triple
Returns:
whether the triple can be inferred by the present model

setLabelManager

void setLabelManager(LabelManager labelManager)
Sets the label manager to be used by this model. The label manager provides optimizations for hierarchy (is-a) queries based on labeling schemes.

The provided label manager must be preconfigured to have as a target this model, i.e. this condition must hold: labelManager.getTargetModel() == this

Parameters:
labelManager - the labelManager to be used by this model
Throws:
IllegalArgumentException - if labelManager.getTargetModel() != this

updateLabels

void updateLabels()
Provides a hint to the underlying LabelManager that it needs to make sure that the labeling of the various hierarchies is updated and ready to be used, so to optimize Inheritable.isAncestorOf(RdfNode)/Inheritable.isDescendantOf(RdfNode) queries.

See Also:
setLabelManager(LabelManager)

updateLabels

void updateLabels(PredefinedLabels predefinedLabels)
Provides a hint to the underlying LabelManager that it needs to make sure that the labeling of the various hierarchies is updated and ready to be used, as updateLabels() does, while it also respects the provided predefined labels.

See Also:
setLabelManager(LabelManager)

addRdfNodeListener

void addRdfNodeListener(RdfNodeListener rdfNodeListener)
Adds a RdfNodeListener to this model, which will be notified on subsequent node events of any node of this model.

Parameters:
rdfNodeListener - the listener to add to this model

removeRdfNodeListener

void removeRdfNodeListener(RdfNodeListener rdfNodeListener)
Removes a RdfNodeListener from this model, meaning it will not be notified on subsequent node events of any node of this model.

If rdfNodeListener is null, nothing happens (i.e. no NullPointerException is thrown).

Parameters:
rdfNodeListener - the listener to remove from this model

addTripleListener

void addTripleListener(TripleListener tripleListener)

Parameters:
tripleListener - the listener to add to this model

removeTripleListener

void removeTripleListener(TripleListener tripleListener)
Removes a TripleListener from this model, meaning it will not be notified on subsequent triple events of this model.

If tripleListener is null, nothing happens (i.e. no NullPointerException is thrown).

Parameters:
tripleListener - the listener to remove from this model

tripleCount

int tripleCount()
Returns the number of Triple instances contained in the model. Even if a triple is contained in multiple named graphs, it is only counted once.

Returns:
the number of Triple instances contained in the indexer
